repnme.cdata!:
Democratic Republic of Congo - Street
            Children Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Street Children Project
            for Democratic Republic of Congo were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            substantial, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory,
            and Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: establish strategic partnerships
            to capitalize on learning and strengthen government
            response. Investing in street children prevention should
            include linkages to economic interventions. One of the few
            intermediary indicator targets that the project did not meet
            was the number of children who benefited from participation
            in a vocational training program. This was largely because
            the age requirement to participate in vocational training is
            15 years and very few of the children living in the street
            were 15 years and above. The project implementation unit
            (PIU) expanded its monitoring and evaluation (M and E)
            capacity by involving social assistants already trained by
            ministry of social affairs, humanitarian action, and
            national solidarity (MINAS) to work with street children.
            These seconded staff improved the PIU’s capacity to verify
            the quality of data its sub grantees were reporting in their
            quarterly reports. Long-term sustainability of results
            depends upon government prioritizing investments in social protection.
